723357f-a.text:
South William Street, east from (No. 34), but not including Broad, to but not including William Street, showing the New York Cotton Exchange Building (with cone shaped roof-corner) which is situated at the S.E. corner of William and Beaver Streets. Most of these buildings still remain up to the present day (1937) with the exception of Nos. 34 to 28 (three houses in the left foreground) which were replaced by the 35-story International Telephone Building and the 4-story house, seen in the centre background, whose site is now occupied by the 11-story building of the Lehman Bros. banking house. The New York Cotton Exchange Building was also razed and was supplanted by a new 24-story modern skyscraper which
is the Exchange's new home.
About 1900.
Brown Brothers.
Meg st WI5oA
723357f-a.folder: South William Street & Broad Street, Manhattan, NY

716870f-c.text:
Broad Street, north from Stone Street. In the midground is Beaver Street, with the lower part of the White Building just appearing. Beyond, at Exchange Place, is the Johnston Building. View 2 is slightly later and includes the Blair and the Mackay Buildings above the latter. On the right is the Mills Building. No. 3 is a slightly more inclusive view. Note the pyramidal Bankers Trust Bldg. completed and the final stages of the Equitable Trust Co. Bldg.
1: About 1895
1906
3: September 1927
Views 1,2fThomas W. Fennedy, photo
Thru Beecher Ogden
Museum Photographers Assn.
View 3: eorge L. Dalgue, photo

716910f-a.text:
84-74 Broad Street, west side, from north of Stone Street to, but not including, Marketfield Street, just south of Beaver Street. The centre building, 80-78 Broad Street, is the Maritime Exchange. This building, and the two adjoining it on the left, will soon give
way to the 36-story Maritime Exchange Building.
June 20, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

716904f-b.text:
67 Broad Street, east side, from South William to Beaver SStreets. This location is that of the 35 storied International Telephone Bldg. which apoears in both views with flag atop. 723359f-b.text:
(1)
43 to 9 South William Street, south side, east from Broad Street, to Mill Lane, showing (foreground) construction work in progress on the 35-story International Telephone Building at the N.E. corner of Broad Street. Contiguous to, and eastward from the construction work, are seen the roof tops of six 4-story houses, Nos. 26 to 14 South William Street. Also shown is a general view eastward of the surrounding ares, with the East River and Brooklyn Bridge in the background. This view was taken from the Produce Exchange Building on Broadway, between Stone
and Beaver Streets.
August 28, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, a more limited view. Also shown (centre foreground) is No. 89-85 Broad Street, east side, between Stone (right) and South William Streets. This 8-story building bears also Nos. 25-29 Stone and No. 43-39 South William Streets. On the extreme right are buildings at the S.E.
corner of Stone and Broad Streets.
August 28, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

716872f-a.text:
Broad Street, west side, north from, but not including, South William Street. I the centre background, the 50-story Irving Trust

716872f-a.folder: Broad Street & William Street (South), Manhattan, NY

716873f-a.text:
(1)
Broad Street, north from, but not including, South William Street. The Beaver Street side of the International Telephone and Telegraph Building has been completed, and work is about to start
on the South William Street portion.
August 20, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, but including South William Street, a year later. The second half of the Iiternational Telephone and Telegraph Building is now completed. Iu the background looms the skeleton of the
60 Wall Street tower.
AuEust 6, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

Broad Street (right), north from Stone Street (foreground, street level not seen), as viexed nnorthwardd from the lew Yorkc Telephone Building at No. 10d Mroad Street. Shown in the backmround are buildinos at Vall Street, consisting of, the lIrving Trust (under construction), the Bankers TTrust (pyramidal roof), the Equitable, and the Equitable Trust Co. Buildings. To the riht foreoround is the new 35 storied International Telephone Building, and to the left, the low Produce Exchange. Viee No. 2 is the same at an earlier date and photographed in the same direction from atop the roof of the last mentioned feature. To the riht in this instance is the 18 story structure (No. 26-28 Beaver Street) shown in the center of the preceding view. Note the absence of the lIrvinm Trust Building and the prominence of te Ecuitable Srust Go. Broad Street is obscured from view by the buildings on the westerly side of same.
Sugust 6, 1930.
No. 2 Auaust 28, 1929.
P. L. Snerr.

716874f-a.text:
Broad Street, north from outh Milliam Street. The low buildings on the right were replaced in 1929 by the 35 story Inernational Telephone Building. (No. 67 Broad Street). Shown in the center are tall structures that from left to right.are, the 17 story Johnston Suilding (subsequently the 48 story Continental Building), the 16 story Mackay (Commercial Cable Co.) Buildings an: the 21 story Broad Exchange Building. The dome seen is atop the Gillenden Building, a structure demolished in 1910 and replaced by the present Bankers Trust Company Building. The 10 story structure at the left is No. 88-64 Broad Street and is at the N.W.corner of Beaver Street. In 1922 this is listed as occupied by the White Oil Company.
April 1906
George L. Balgue
716874f-a.folder: Broad Street & William Street (South), Manhattan, NY

716875f-a.text:
Broad Street, north from South Milliam Street. The low buildings on the right were replaced in 1929 by the 35 story Inernational Telephone Building. (No. 67 Broad Street). Shown in the center are tall structures that from left to right.are, the 17 story Johnston Suilding (subsequently the 48 story Continental Building), the 16 story Mackay (9ommercial Cable Co.) Buildings an: the 21 story Broad Exchange Building. The dome seen is atop the Gillenden Building, a structure demolished in 1910 and replaced by the present Bankers Trust Company Building. The 10 story structure at the left is No. 68-64 Broad Street and is at the N.W.corner of Beaver Street. In 1922 this is listed as occupied by the White Oil Company.
April 1908
George L. Balgue

Herald Tribune Editorial Art Dept.
AAE. Lefcourt's latest building achievement --- the new 57,000,000 International Telephone Building which opens it doors next Tuesday, Nay 1st, with every scduare foot of space leased, establishing an unparalleded leasing record.
67 Broad Street

716909f-a.text:

background.
May 12, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

723431f-b.text:
24-40 Stone Street, south side, east from, but not including Broad Street, to Coenties Alley. No. 32 (the 3-story house with the gabled roof, in] the center of the view), is more than 100 years old, now serving as the home ; of the American Banker; a bank publication. In 1835, this building had its narrowest escape when the Great Fire of that year, which laid the greater part of that section south of Wall Street in ruins, burned up to the building's.
side of wall, and went no farther.
August 28, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
N~Aieee,fo7 Wecg ~eg~24
(2)
A view showing prominently the American Banker home at No. 32
Stone Street. To the left is a Manhattan pecularity, a structure on
a 8.1O E 35.6 foot plot, bearing No. 32S.
